Thanks Ken. It is very cool and reassuring to see how easily CPPNs and meet
the challenge I threw down. I am convinced. Now I just wish we had the tool
you mentioned hooked up to these images so we could see how they are
accomplishing this feat!




Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Sat, 30 Aug 2008 20:58:04 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: An argument in favor of developmental processes?
> 
> Jeff, that's a good thought experiment for testing my claim.  There
> are many considerations, and although I may not hit all of them, I
> think in general it can be refuted:
> 
> Generally, I think HyperNEAT (i.e. NEAT with CPPNs) already
> approximately follow the scenario that you outline:  It discovers key
> motifs (whether they be skin or something else) early in evolution and
> then as the overall body plan is deformed, the original motifs are
> often preserved (which again includes skin).  The main idea is that
> skin is like a kind of surrounding motif for the overall shape, and if
> the pverall shape is warped through some kind of mutation in the
> internal CPPN, then however the shape is surrounded will naturally
> warp in the same way.
> 
> In fact, you can see this happen consistently in Picbreeder.  It is
> possible to consider the simple black outline of many of the color
> figures as a "skin."  You can notice that it is special by noting that
> often the outer band is black but everything structure inside is
> color.  Then, if the shape of the overall image warps, so does the
> outer membrane.
> 
> However, you might say that such a "skin" is not complex enough to be
> convincing.  Perhaps skin should have multiple parts, i.e. its own
> special structure.  In fact, if you look closely, you can find many
> such examples.  For example, there are often double-layer outer
> membranes that form, such as in this image:
> 
> http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=317
> 
> There is a clear outer structure that surrounds the complex curvature
> of the object.
> 
> Or, perhaps more interestingly, you can get several layers of color
> bands, but only on the outer membrane, such as in this image that ends
> in a light blue that becomes green, then becomes yellow, before
> sinking into the inner-body color of orange:
> 
> http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=4227
> 
> To show that the outer membrane warps easily and naturally regardless
> of shape changes (even complex ones), I further evolved that image to
> get a new shape, and you can see that the outer membrane has the same
> motif nevertheless, nicely warped to accommodate the new overall shape:
> 
> http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=5635
> 
> It is also important to note that outer membranes in nature are not
> uniform covers and often transition into something else on the
> surface.  For example, consider lips and eyes.  Or perhaps even more
> importantly, consider fingernails, where the outer cover actually
> falls *under* something else (i.e. the nail), violating the covering
> rule.  I point these exceptions out because in Picbreeder you also
> often see almost consistent outer motifs that are broken in a couple
> places.  While these locations often are arbitrary, the point is that
> such a capability could be exploited if it actually mattered.
> 
> Moving from 2-D to 3-D should not matter in the case of skin, just as
> moving CPPNs from 2-D to 4-D continues to allow all the same
> regularities.  So when you see examples in 2-D, they are also possible
> in 3-D for the same reasons.
> 
> Most of these outer skin motifs can arise early when the shape is
> simple and are then easily preserved.  However, they are not always
> preserved.  For example, the multicolor skin above evolved into a
> different multicolor skin in one lineage:
> 
> http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=4228
> 
> This phenomenon is expected from the analogy with nature, just as
> scales can evolve into fur, or fur into uncovered skin, all still
> serving the role of outer membrane.
> 
> I think it's important to note that skin or an outer membrane is not
> really any different from any other CPPN-generated motif, in that it
> can be preserved, warped, or changed in its internal structure.  So I
> don't think there is really anything special going on in the argument
> compared to the discovery of symmetry or other conventions.
> 
> ken 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Hello all-
>> 
>> Ken has challenged us all many times to think about whether there is any
>> need for a process of development. The identity of cells in
> developmental
>> processes is determined by local contextual information whereas Ken
>> advocates skipping that by letting cells determine their identity
> via giving
>> them their objective coordinates. The question is whether we lose
> anything
>> important to the evolution of complexity by skipping this step.
>> 
>> I think it is a fascinating question and, unable to come up with a good
>> reason why development matters myself, but wanting to give the
> argument a
>> rigorous evaluation, I have been asking many people in our field whether
>> they can describe something unique that a developmental process
> provides. No
>> one has come up with  a reason that compels me, so I have become a
> strong
>> advocate of the lack of a need for an unfolding process.
>> 
>> However, in the course of watching a keynote on development in natural
>> systems at this year's gecco, an argument in favor of development
> occurred
>> to me that may have merit. I am interested to hear what y'all think
> of it.
>> 
>> The argument is this: it might be easier to evolve certain large-scale
>> properties when the organism is simple and small and then scale/grow
> them
>> up, rather than incorporating them into an already complex phenotype. I
>> think an example illustrates the point best. Imagine evolution
> figuring out
>> how to put a coat of skin on an organism. It is not that hard to
> figure out
>> what the shape of that skin should be when the embryo has only a few
> cells.
>> Once that simple and small coat of skin has formed, it can follow
> the simple
>> rule of keeping the layer of skin the same thickness, and adding cells
>> within that layer to grow to cover any arbitrary shape that the
> phenotype
>> becomes. This simple rule could produce a skin shell for a bat or a
> jaguar.
>> Now consider how hard it would be for 3D hyperneat to create a skin
> shell
>> for a bat or a jaguar. The mathematical function to create such
> outlines is
>> very complex (although it is less so if it is a composition of other,
>> already created functions that produced the rest of the body). Still, it
>> seems that this task might be harder for hyperneat than following
> the simple
>> developmental rules outlined above.
>> 
>> What do you think? I would happily be convinced that this argument is
>> without merit, so please let me know if you see any problems with it.
>> 
>> 
>> Cheers,
>> Jeff Clune
>> 
>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
>> 
>> jclune@...
>> 
> 
>
